title: Entropy
videoTitle: ME40 - Video 7 - Principle of Maximum Entropy (edited)

subtopics.title: Carnot cycle analysis
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius analyzes a Carnot cycle. He derives the thermal efficiency of an engine operating in a Carnot cycle. He then gives Carnot's theorem.
subtopics.detailed_summary: The lecture begins with an analysis of the **Carnot cycle** on a $T-S$ (Temperature-Entropy) diagram. The cycle, which operates between a high temperature $T_1$ and a low temperature $T_2$, consists of four reversible processes: **isothermal expansion** ($A \to B$ at $T_1$), **isentropic expansion** ($B \to C$), **isothermal compression** ($C \to D$ at $T_2$), and **isentropic compression** ($D \to A$). The professor explains that isentropic processes are also adiabatic (no heat transfer). For the isothermal steps, the change in entropy is defined as $\Delta S = \frac{Q}{T}$. Since this is a cycle, the **net change in entropy for the entire cycle is zero** ($\Delta S_{cycle} = 0$). This condition mathematically demonstrates the relationship $\frac{Q_1}{T_1} = \frac{Q_2}{T_2}$. The **net work output** ($W_{net}$) is shown to be equivalent to the net heat absorbed ($Q_1 - Q_2$) and is visually represented as the rectangular area enclosed by the cycle on the $T-S$ diagram.

subtopics.title: Principle of maximum entropy
subtopics.summary: Prof. Schutzius explains that processes are more likely to occur in an isolated system when the entropy increases.
subtopics.detailed_summary: The lecture introduces the **Principle of Increase in Entropy**, which is the statement of the **Second Law of Thermodynamics**. This law states that the **entropy of the universe** (the system plus its surroundings) must always **increase or remain constant** ($\Delta S_{univ} \ge 0$). **Reversible (ideal) processes** result in $\Delta S_{univ} = 0$, while all **irreversible (real-world) processes** result in $\Delta S_{univ} > 0$. The core concept is the **Principle of Maximum Entropy**, which posits that an isolated system will spontaneously proceed in a direction that **increases its entropy** until it reaches a state of **maximum possible entropy at equilibrium**. Any process that would decrease the universe's entropy is deemed impossible. The professor stresses that this principle, alongside the conservation of mass, momentum, and energy, represents the fundamental rules that govern all physical processes.
